column1: Mariehamn (Swedish pronunciation; Finnish: Maarianhamina) is the capital of the Åland Islands
column2: an autonomous territory under Finnish sovereignty. Mariehamn is the seat of the Government and Parliament of Åland
column3: and 40% of the population of Åland live in the city. It is mostly surrounded by Jomala
column4: the second largest municipality in Åland in terms of population; to the east it is bordered by Lemland. Like all of Åland
column5: Mariehamn is unilingually Swedish-speaking and around 88% of the inhabitants speak it as their native language.

column1: The town was named after the Russian empress Maria Alexandrovna. Mariehamn was founded in 1861
column3: in what was at the time part of the municipality of Jomala. The city has since expanded and incorporated more of Jomala territory. Mariehamn was built according to a very regular scheme which is well-preserved. One of the oldest streets is Södragatan where many wooden houses dating from the 19th century can be seen.

column1: Following the First World War Mariehamn was home to the Mariehamn Grain Fleet.
The city is located on a peninsula. It has two important harbours
column2: one located on the western shore and one on the eastern shore
column3: which are ice-free for nearly the whole year
column4: and have no tides. The Western Harbour is an important international harbour with daily traffic to Sweden
column5: Estonia and mainland Finland.  A powerful incentive for Baltic ferries to stop at Mariehamn is that
column7: Åland is not part of the EU customs zone and so duty-free goods can be sold aboard.

column1: Åland and Mariehamn have a reputable heritage in shipping. The Flying P-Liner Pommern museum ship is anchored in the Western Harbour. The Eastern Harbour features one of the largest marinas in Scandinavia. The famous Dutch steamer Jan Nieveen (now called F.P. von Knorring
column2: after Åland teacher and vicar Frans Peter von Knorring) can also be found here.

column1: Mariehamn Airport serves the city; it has scheduled flights on two airlines including Finnair.
The city is an important centre for Åland media; both of the local newspapers (Ålandstidningen and Nya Åland)
column2: several radio stations and the local TV channels (TV Åland and Åland24) operate out of the city. The islanders are traditionally fond of reading
column3: and had public libraries before 1920. A printing works was established in the town in 1891. The municipal library
column5: is one of the most interesting modern buildings.

column1: Mariehamn features several buildings drawn by Finnish architect Lars Sonck
column2: who moved to Åland as a child. Buildings drawn by him include the church of Mariehamn (1927)
column3: the main building of the Åland Maritime College (1927) and the town hall (1939). Hilda Hongell also designed several buildings
column4: although only a few are still standing.

column1: Mariehamn has a transitional climate between humid continental climate (Dfb) with certain maritime influence as a result of the strong maritime moderation from being an island in the Baltic Sea. This renders summers to be cooler than both the Swedish and Finnish mainlands
column2: with winters being similar in cold to the adjacent coastal part of Sweden but milder than Finland's mainland. The lowest temperature at Mariehamn airport was -32.9 C (-27.2F) in February 1979
column3: and the highest temperature on record was 31.3 C (88.3F) in July 1941.
